It's surprisingly large with a lot of open world opportunity, but also a clear path for linear progression. The characters and lore are fascinating, engaging and keep you wanting more. The game play is easy enough to understand to progress, but has layers for additional difficulty and is very rewarding to stray off course and battle/collect things. There's a TON to do, but you never feel inundated by the vastness, it's a very happy medium with a lot to love.

Still better than Cyberpunk 2077
One of the best games ever made.

If you are a fan of open world games, at least try this game. The map is beautiful and well detailed, the storyline is incredible, the sidequests are perfect, the gameplay is decent, and the music is something else. Don't even bother playing Gwent you will lose.. a lot. Anyway, get this game for your own benefit.

After playing through the base game twice and now just finishing the DLC's. I can write my review with confidence. Never have I played a game so rewarding. Every aspect of this game I have fallen in love with. The game is incredibly story-rich, married with the combat it makes for a truly rewarding game. What I love about this game especially is that your decisions have consequences that make the game that so much more interactive. I would recommend highly this game to anybody, especially those that love an excellent story, with such good voice acting and mo-cap animations too.

I could talk about how much I enjoyed playing this game for hours, but I will try and keep my review brief.

Voice acting top notch, I could criticise the lack of variety on non-mission NPCs but that is just the sprinkels on the frosting on this awesome cake.

One of the greatest games of modern times

They certainly dumbed down the series since the last release. Sure it raked in a larger audience but it sacrificed what is was previously in the process, which was once well written and unique instead became copy-paste and bland. The game completely omits that Triss did nothing but screw Geralt over with everything she's done involving for the Sorceresses Lodge, most likely just to have her as a romance option. This isn't the only thing it omits either.

Nothing says player hand holding like Geralt's *detective vision* removing any player involvement in questing, and Geralt's permanent monologuing to ensure the player knows what they're seeing scene to scene on the rollercoaster. Most quests will follow the same formula of: Talk to person > get told to go somewhere > while at somewhere, learn the person you talked to first is morally dubious > but so is the new person you meet in the quest > get money from either person and move on to next quest.

The combat isn't as good as the predecessor, there's very little thought put into it, which isn't really Witcher-like. Unsure how many variants of "x time of day" wraith there really are, but they're overused in this. 

Gwent was a good minigame, and the minigame shouldn't be more enjoyable than the actual game. Unfortunately, Gwent was also poorly balanced. Fixed by the spin off expansion of Gwent that you can play instead with more balance, but more child friendly too, because swearing is bad.

All in all it's a shame, they had some fantastic ideas in the game that were ruined by trying to dumb everything else down as much as possible. It's also a great and interesting world. The gameplay is dull and generic. Quite the "meh" experience, for what could have been so much more.

I don't recommend this game unless you have played the Witcher 1 and 2. Sure, this is a great game, but many things don't make sense without context. Who's Foltest? Why should you care about Dandelion? etc. It is a heavily story-based series. The combat and a lot of mini-quests are not actually that great. The quests range from good to incredible, but you will simply miss too much if you skip the first two games. The payoff that you get from being a lowly amnesiac in the first game to a living legend by the end of this one makes it all worth it.

Now, as for the game itself, a great theme of the Witcher series is choice, and the Witcher 3 has them in abundance. Be careful not to save scum or spoil your way out of every bad situation. For one, some choices don't have immediate effects, and these effects are not always black and white; for the other, there is a great lesson to be had in each bad decision. The game makes you realize not just what you did wrong, but how you did wrong, in an almost philosophical way, which is quite a rare thing. I would say there are many instances of dilemmas such as the "trolley problem", where it is not clear whether your interference is a net "good". Of course, when you do make a decision you are happy with, you certainly feel better about yourself, but there is value in neutrality, which is also another overarching theme the Witcher tries to teach you.

Overall, there are many layers to this game, but I don't want to spoil everything. There is much fun to be had, but that is only if you played the Witcher 1 and 2.

Read the books, played previous two games plenty of times. 
The only thing I noticed is that when you play the 3rd while not having played the other 2 games, 
you are playing a different game. And the same if you played only the 3 games and not the books.
Having that said, I highly recommend this game as an experience.

If you are new to the Witcher universe, always read every piece of journal entry or info you get. 
It will help u a lot.Take your time, don't rush it. I hope u have fun.

A game in 2015 has no business being this good, the world is stuffed with things to find and contracts to do.
The characters are interesting and very well written. Honestly Geralt the 2nd best protagonist in video game history. the first being Arthur Morgan.
For a game about a witcher without emotions there are some very powerful scenes with Geralt which I won't spoil.
I completed all of the contracts, done many of the side quests and did all of the subplots and Im sure I haven't experienced everything this game has to offer.
I bought this game for 15$ and I cant recommend is enough.

A worthy capstone to the Witcher-Saga of games, although it is kind of funny how vastly superior the DLCs stories are to the main plot of the base game.

The Witcher 3 is near aesthetic perfection. The modular animation system is so seamless that I hardly ever notice it. The camera work for each conversation and scene keeps things interesting visually, and voice acting and music tie it all together. The conversation and choice systems are extremely well fleshed out, and the amount of an effect that player choice has on the story is highly commendable on CDPRs part. HOWEVER, the gameplay really dragged this game down for me. The inventory ui pisses me off as a graphic designer/normal fucking person, and the crafting is extremely tedious. The fighting is slippery, unintuitive, and inconsistent, although it does look very nice most of the time. Merely running around is awkward, and Geralt gets hung up on small bits of geometry or items a lot. The RPG statistics and such were far to complicated for me, as someone who primarily comes to these games for the scenery and writing. It's a rather large and unnecessary roadblock to all of the other content within this game. Also, people need to stop putting weapon degradation in their games purely for realism and immersion. If there isn't a gameplay purpose for weapon degradation, it shouldn't be in the game. If you enjoy complex RPG stat management, then you might enjoy this on normal, otherwise play it on it's easiest setting.

The most masterfully crafted RPG of this generation by far, The Witcher 3 blows you away with an incredible main story and side quests, detailed and meaningful choices, graphics that still look incredible to this day (the environment detail is ballslapping), a soundtrack that makes you FEEL like you're in the middle of a medieval fantasy adventure (with a lot of influences from Eastern European culture) and really good gameplay which has weight and makes you feel like a legendary sword fighter. 

With over 500 hrs played on GOG and PS4, replaying this again on Steam is a joy and I can say it is still just as enjoyable as when I first tried it. Completely recommend buying it.

While there is a lot of content, the game loves to waste your time by filling huge amounts of time with mindless/idle activities such as riding your horse from point A to point B or having to walk to a signpost to fast travel. There are also tons of filler quests that have no impact on the story at all and boil down to killing a few monsters. On a positive note, Gwent is the best minigame in any game I've played. However, after 10+ hours I was already finding myself bored of the dull combat and repetitive quest design. I eventually added mods to try to improve the experience (multiple quest icons, fast travel from anywhere, other misc QOL mods) but even after adding these basic features that should have been in the game in the first place, it still was not compelling enough to continue.
Eines der wenigen Spiele dieser Art die ich wirklich gut finde, unendlich lange story (bin mit aktuell 76h immer noch nicht fertig) und auch jetzt noch tolle Grafik!

Great story, interesting characters, engaging card game side quest, but true to its reputation a very long game. Even Geralt sounded tired at times.

The Good: I have been on and off this game several times over the years. Each time I return, I know there is plenty of unexplored world and content awaiting me. Money worth? Definitely. With updated quest journal, beast glossary (and my previously saved mouse key bindings), it really wasn't difficult to get back into the rhythm.

The Bad: Developers obviously do not understand the meaning of the word "Climax" and "Final". All the while I was progressing in the main quest and about to reach the "Final" battle to kick the last boss back to before he was born. And after that close encounter, I find myself still have to go through even more quests to find him to fight him again! Like, I need to go find a dude to ask about some stone, who in turn refer me to two other dudes. Seriously man, if the game does not reach a peak, its called a plateau. Ever wondered why so many players gave up and dropped out of this beloved game? And I think I have been on and about this "Final" main quest for days now! Only this time when I am done typing this review, I hope it will finally be final in maybe another 10, 20 hours? Geez, anticlimax. You don't build up players expectations to drag on.

After I am done with this "final", I need to reconsider starting the purchased expansions immediately after. Need a change in scenery and environment. Like what I said, another on and off the game, again.
Nothing much to say, definitely a perfect game!

I was late to the hype party before the game released, so I had not years of expectation that i know many had. And I can't speak for those. But for me I really had an amazing time playing, I think the stories are really interesting and it keep me wanting to play.
Ofc there is buggs, but nothing that ruined the gaming experience for me. I had to restart the game 1 time and reload my saved 2 times through my whole playthrough, becuase of a bugg. That's it, and for a new game this is expected. Maybe I was lucky? Anyway, I had an amazing time and looking forward for a second playthrough.

Probably the greatest RPG I have ever played. I cannot think of a single grievance with the game aside from a few bugs here and there that force you to load up a recent save. After 4-5 years the game still holds up really well graphically and mechanically. Sure the combat can be a bit tedious and/or one dimensional, but there are plenty of choices to change the combat/encounters to suit your liking. The Witcher lore essentially adapts Scandinavian folk lore, myths, and legends into a living universe, so there are a lot of familiar creatures an story beats, but with bit of a twist. Basically modern Brothers Grimm.

Highly recommend 20 out of 10

[b] Alright, I am aware of how many good things have been said about the game, another positive review might be pointless. I am here just to point out some things that are rarely said and to let off steam from playing this game. I am going to divide the review in parts that I wanted to point out so that it's more digestible. [/b]

[b] [u] MAIN STORY [/u] [/b]
This game's story is prett-ty dark. Like I'll gladly categorize this as a dark fantasy rpg kind of story. You often don't quite expect the outcome of certain actions that is often done in other games, and I'll have to say it's somewhat [b] realistic [/b] because the outcome is probably what would happen if said scenario were to happen in the real world, and as a [i] witcher [/i] (oversimplified, a monster bounty hunter) you'll come across A LOT of grim situations. Lemme give you an example: [spoiler] "You were tasked to get back a certain person loved ones that have been gone for 2 days in the woods." In the real world you'd might expect the worst already but this is a game right? haha surely they'll be alive... NO. 90% of these encounters the realistic thing happened, the loved ones dead and the quest giver will begin their 5 stages of grief right in front of you before you received your payment in which it would be very awkward to ask. [/spoiler] 
Don't worry though, there are quite a few of happy moments, it's not a completely dark story after all, and these moments don't last forever, so you'll be sure to cherish these!
Oh, I also want to give a new player a tip in making decision, be carefree. You might never expect what would happen y'know :)

[b] [u] GAME ACCESSIBILITY [/u] [/b]
This is a big point that haven't been said enough to a player wanting to pick up this game.

If you're an [b] outsider of The Witcher franchise [/b], you might be asking, "is it okay to just jump into The Witcher 3 without ever knowing the previous games and books?", the answer is a YES. It's okay to just play this game, although, as expected, you might be confused in the early hours of the game. Don't worry though, you got a Character Book (default key: G.) that'll tell you what there is to know about the character to fully enjoy the game, after some reading you won't feel quite left out anymore when the characters are talking. Besides that, there are YouTube videos online that'll cover The Witcher lore, but beware, as for this game is quite spoiler heavy, meaning there's a lot of story points that can be spoiled and it can happen easily.

Now, in my opinion, the biggest barrier that made me cannot recommend this to everyone is the [b] language barrier. [/b] This game, I think, uses a lot of Old English phrases that can be quite hard to understand for the Modern English speaking folk. I personally HAVE to play it with Google Translate in the Steam Overlay just to understand what're these [i] ploughing [/i] phrases mean! Although I am not a native English speaker, so that may be a factor in my difficulty. If your native tongue is lucky enough available as a subtitle, you can go ahead not do that translating deed. But, at the other end, this game can be quite a source to understand plenty heavy, majestic, master looking words, like [i] colloquially, frippery, [/i] and others that you can use in the internet to virtually raise your social status!

Game difficulty's fine... you can change it in the middle of a playthrough, so don't worry about that. You can look up others take on difficulty if you're still curious.

[b] [u] THE BUGSSSSSSSSSSSS [/u] [/b]
Oh god, the bugs. How the hell did people not see Cyberbug 2077 coming?! This game, after 5 years and more, IS STILL riddled with bugs. Mind you, it's not game breaking bugs that you can see in Cyberbug, but still, I'd say the amount of it is similar to recent Assassin's Creed games! You got the input bug, such as not being able to attack in the middle of a fight, not being able to sprint horses, alt+tab sometimes doesn't work, to graphical bugs, such as texture pop in (quite rare), hair and tree flailing around in cutscenes at an unrealistic rate, and lots, lots of clipping the latter of which can be fixed with mods thankfully (gonna talk more about this). The solution of most of these bugs are just reloading your saves (enabling autosave is a must for this reason) which can take variably depending on your system, if you got HDD, well, you're in for a long time of waiting.

[b] [u] MODDING DIFFICULTY [/u] [/b]
Alright this will be my last point, won't bore you too long with reading, the modding in this game is pretty accessible, not as much as to say, Skyrim, but still pretty friendly nonetheless. After 2 hours of straight reading (i think? i dunno i was immersed in modding) of multiple instructions on how to mod the game, I already got the gist of it and pretty much able to troubleshoot any mod installed. In my opinion, you'll need 3 tools, the most important one is The Witcher 3 Mod Manager (fan made and still recent). This will take care all the tedious stuff of installing a mod and can uninstall easily. The next 2 are Script Merger and Mod Merger. You can read the rest in [url=https://docs.google.com/document/d/1wFmn7PEarcJsHnZC67PJyFJ8wbpFLP3eFeBh171WuRM/edit#] here [/url] should tell you everything about basic modding. Beware though, as this game is quite fragile with mods in my experience, so you might wanna create a backup.
As for mod availability, it's pretty huge, due to the new The Witcher Netflix series, interest in the game spiked back up and thus with big demand, the most of the mods are updated to the newest version, so you'll rarely find any outdated mods in your modding.

Alright, that's about it from me, thank you for reading this if you did, you have my thanks. Today is still a great time to jump into The Witcher 3 to experience it for the first time, or as a returning player with interest in mods.

Pro:
Each quest and NPC has it's own story which is amazing.
Artwork and soundtrack are great.
Plenty of builds you can go for and items you can use.
Really enjoyed the horse racing events, brawler and gwent games.
Con:
The combat mechanics would have greatly benefited from some polishing.
Terrain and object interaction could have been better (especially horse riding).
A handful of bugs left behind that brake a bit the immersion of the game.
Some overpowered enemies (eg. caretaker).
The enchantment crafting is way to expensive when compared with your income.
The huge number of point of interest in skellige isles is just boring to clear.
The grand master-crafted sets and the extended talent tree are available too late in the game.

Overall, a very good game with a great story and good role-playing experience.
Would definitely play again and recommend to other players.
Buy this game, you will not regret it

Phenomenal game with rich, gritty and deep stories all the way from the main quest line down to the smallest of side quests. This game puts forth an immersive realistic and morally ambiguous fantasy world in which, much like real life, you're often faced with dilemmas and the right course of action is not always apparent. You'll at times be faced with seemingly simple decisions that turn out to have far reaching consequences, trying to do the right thing can backfire dramatically and many times there is no right thing to do at all as you're forced to choose between multiple negative outcomes. If you like dark, story driven 3rd person action RPG's and you somehow haven't played this yet then I highly recommend it!

But ironically this version has a lot more bugs compared to when I pirated it. Did I miss some patches??

One of the most beautiful and entertaining games I've ever played, perhaps top of the list of all time. Maintains a respect for the source material while also creating a whole world as itself. I would not recommend this game for children or those of high religious values. There is violence, gore, nudity, and sexual scenes, just as there was plenty of in the book series that spawned the game series. None of those things listed are to the point of excess. The violence and gore fit the work and times depicted in the story line. The nudity and sexual scenes are brief and not grotesque or overtly graphic. If I'm writing this as a genuine review, I feel that the positives far outweigh any perceived negatives.

TLDR version: the game is friggin sweet.
This game was good, but not the greatest RPG I've ever played. The story was good though.
I held off getting this game for way too long I've been playing it a bunch and absolutely loving it, it really is amazing not a perfect game but well worth the price

One of if not the best RPGs of all time:
- Simple yet very intriguing plot
- Memorable, well-developed characters (#TeamRoach)
- Variety of choices and consequences, think before action
- Fun combat
- A lot of exploration
- GWENT
- Mind-blowing soundtracks
- The attention to detail is just ... incredible 
- Tremendously high replayability
- The dev made two great games and called them DLCs

This game will make you forget what real life is.
Ich mag das Spiel auch wenn ich noch nicht viel gespielt habe.
Been a gamer all my life and this one is the best ive played hands down 10/10

This is genuinely the best single-player game I have ever played and is well worth the money, especially when you can find it on sale. Would highly recommend buying the GOTY edition though because it is not that much more expensive and gives you both expansion at a much better deal than if you were to buy them seperately.

after serious consideration, I think this game is not a good game.
I've tried multiple times but failed to enjoy it. I thought it was my fault that a universally praised game that I don't enjoy. but now I'm pretty clear that this"game" (if it ever was a game) was never a game, just a story telling application with little interactions.

Witcher 3 as an entertainment maybe worth for a group of people, but plz don't call it a game or even "the game of the decade", it doesn't deserve it.

Oyun gayet gÃ¼zel grafikleri olsun hikayenin akÄ±ÅŸÄ± falan iyi hoÅŸ ama bir tane yaratÄ±kta takÄ±ldÄ±m en az 10 kere denedim kesmeye yaklaÅŸamadÄ±m bile Ã¼stelik normal modda oynuyorum bi ara geri baÅŸlÄ±yacaÄŸÄ±m ama dediÄŸim gibi bazÄ± bosslar Ã§ok zor.

The Witcher 3 is the greatest game ever made, idc what u say, that's a fact. I have over 3000+ hours on Xbox, and as soon as i got a PC its the first thing i bought. 
The grittiness and brutality of this game's atmosphere and combat is unreal, CD has really created a world where u can be immersed and become Geralt of Rivia. 
The side characters are believable and lovable and Geralt has been an amazing protagonist since the first game and i'm really sad that his story has ended, but at least he went out with a bang.
I think the worst part of this game is that I cant play it 24/7, just cos i have to sleep n shit.

Imagine you're watching an extremely well directed and well written TV show. This show has developed it's very own universe where the protagonist is free to make choices and is liable to face the consiquences derived from the choices that were made. In this show every character has their own experiences and motivations, basically there are shades of grey instead of all black and white. 
Now imagine being Colosally imersed in this TV show except this is not a TV show but a game which you can play and command according to your will. 
That's Witcher 3 for you.

Still buggy, but the bugs are minor. I can't say there's much diversity in character development (I mean the skill tree), for there are no builds basically, but the system is complex and not dull.  But where this game shines the most is the story, quests, atmosphere and small details, a big and worth exploring world.

A very good game filled with tons of exploration and monsters. The side quests, unlike other RPGs, arent copy and paste fetch quests but feel like an extension of the world. Though the story is nothing amazing in my opinion it had its moments. The only problem is that this game is very buggy. I got both the DLC's and the base game for 15 bucks and at that price or the base price, you'd be crazy not to pick it up.

Le magie, lo status e anche l'abilitÃ  e l'alchimia si livellano con i punti abilitÃ  che ricevi quando Gerard livella ma bisogna riflettere bene dove assegnare i punti per progredire il PG nel migliore dei modi. L'unico neo di questo capolavoro sono i dialoghi con i sottotitoli in italiano ovviamente, ma secondo me una gioco del genere di questa portata doveva essere doppiato in Italiano, vabbÃ¨ ci tocca leggere heheheh. Ho giÃ  scritto troppo per questo bellissimo gioco bhe... che aspetti mettilo in LIBRERIA!!!!

I put off playing this game for years, until I had a good enough box to play it, and just finished it. I won't write a long review, but will say that this is the richest open world fantasy RPG ever made. Red Dead 2 is the only game that is equivalent, and both are shining examples of how to produce a game as art. Anyone who has not played this amazing game needs to pick it up and play through it - get the DLCs, too, they are amazing as well. Great ending, better than anything you'd find in any TV series. Only a well written series of novels would give you the same experience. Look, just get it and be done with it if you like well-done fantasy worlds or like solid action RPGs.

after playing thru the whole base game+the DLCs i can say this game has to be one of the best i've played.The Story is great,there is alot of secondary quests,"treasure hunts" and world to explore or if you want to chill you can just play the ingame card game

Finally got around to playing it and has lived up to all my expectations. Plus the modding community is amazing.
Shit ton of content. You want content, you get content.

The best game I've played to date. 
Immersive, fun, sad, scary and funny all at the same time, for it's time, this game is an absolute masterpiece. 
I've immersed myself for nearly 200 hours and still have more quests available, the dialog actually has an impact on the story and the character's communication with you, the skill trees and alchemy, crafting etc systems are great, I LOVE how much content there is in the base game, not even going into the DLC's which are also insane. 
I honestly couldn't recommend this game any more highly if I tried, you like medieval women? Got it. You like mythical creatures? Got it. You like fighting other people, archery, sword play? Got it. I honestly believe there's something in this game for everyone, I can't wait for the next gen update to experience it all over again!

Gripping story, compelling characters. If you're going into this without having played W1 and W2, I'd suggest to play them first. W1's controls are horrible, but it is worth it for the story, it gives context for all that is to come, and a LOT is to come. I couldn't wait to get to W2, which was a nice upgrade in a lot of gameplay-related areas, if not directly the story part (a bit short).

To give a bit of context, I started to play W3 in 2020 Oct. or so, not having played the previous games. Felt like I was missing something, lots of references to past events and experiences, in dialogs with characters, and it annoyed me a more and more as it went on. So about ~80 hours in, I bit the bullet, put W3 down, bought W1+W2 on GOG, and started again from the very beginning. And I gotta tell you, it was WORTH IT!

64 hours of W1, 45 hours of W2, and finally, ~200 hours after starting a new W3 game from the W2 save, it is done. And what a ride it was. Ups and downs, lovable characters, hatable characters, lovable AND hatable characters, hard decisions, and overall an emotional rollercoaster. It was never boring, not even the most menial of sidequests. And I'm sad that it came to an end, but every story has to end once.

And I've gotta say, the two DLC-s are a must, (but buy them in a discounted GOTY package or so). The DLC-s help with the letting to part, and help is needed after such an epic arc of a story. They are both good little stories of their own, with a kind of an extended conclusion to the main story (BnW even takes place in a beatiful, whole new fairytale-like area).

If you like story-rich adventure games, and a bit of hack-n-slash (this is more the former), liked the series, then you'll most probably enjoy it. and I'd suggest you to give it a go!

As a long-term fan of RPG's, this one hits all the marks! As a magic-wielding, dual-sword bearing Witcher, there is a great Skyrim feel to the quests. The story line is great, with consequences to your choices during gameplay. Against the lore, I've decided to thoroughly hate Yennefer. 

Highly recommend, and great re-play value!

Yes o yes one of my favorite games and is heartbreaking with the story. the graphics are pretty good and GREAT for a 2015 game. this game has the best story of any game i have played and has a good combat system. the map is HUGE and when i say huge i mean prob as big as GTA 5 map huge OR BIGGER [there are a few]. I'll start by saying that I've been a gamer since the 80's, and have played more RPG's than I can remember, and this is far and beyond the best of the best. The visuals and storyline are on par with Red Dead 2, (which I purchased later) and it's one of few RPG's I've barely felt the need to mod. Just the High Res Re-texture and a few very small mods. To me, this says a lot about the polish put on this game by CD PROJEKT RED. FO4 and Skyrim are both beyond 100 mods per as I play them. Mainly because of a lack of content that should have been in the game in the first place. I saw very little need to mod TW3, and for me and I'm sure others, that's a very high compliment.  The story and voice acting at 10/10. If you're looking for a good RPG,  and are bored of the straight forward hack and slay style play with bad voice acting and a stale storyline, then get The Witcher 3. And sit back and watch the wonderful story unfold.
Beautifull game, superduper immersive, one of the best RPG

The game can be quite confusing when you start out, but you learn how combat works early on and the rest of the RPG mechanics like armor and weapon values, signs, and experience are relatively easy to figure out once you learn how you like to fight and how you like to play the game in general. Would highly recommend picking up mods like AutoLoot and Friendly HUD to make exploring easier and less of a hassle, but they aren't vital to core game play. Also, if you don't follow the wiki to the letter to get all the best results, you can expect to feel like a horrible person regardless of your best intentions. Good Luck!

This game is fantastic, it has an amazing story that i would rate 10 / 10. It is to this day my favourite game of all time, and a lot of factors contribute to that. One is for the character's, all the characters have a fantastic backstory and your decisions make a big impact on how you end the game. Another reason is the detailed contracts / side quests which i haven't seen in many other games. Every single contract and quest is different and not repetitive at all which is a common theme for some games such as Skyrim. And of course the graphics are fantastic in this game, even for a game that came out in 2015, it has astonishing graphics that could compete with some modern titles. I picked this game up on a sale not expecting much other than my friend saying it has good graphics and the story is good. I just thought it was gonna be another medieval game where the whole game is going through dungeons and grabbing an item for a character only to do that same thing again for another character, but it is so much more and i truly do recommend this game.
Don't buy it if you value your time, otherwise it's a great investment

The story is 10/10. Gameplay needs a bit of polishing. If I walk into fences or tree, I have to spend a good 2-3 second unsticking myself from it. Swordplay feels really repetitive and I can't seem to get parry timing down with monster. User interface could use some work. The tutorials will shove itself into your face every time you open up a menu. Yes, it is an RPG in the sense that you can pick what skills you want to level up, but it's mostly just +1 damage and that kind of stuff. What makes it worse is that you can only have a few abilities active, so you better be careful what you put your points into. You do get to choose what kind of armor you wear, so you can play a bit of fashion-Witcher. Gwent, the ingame card game is kinda cool. If a vendor sells cards, buy them.

Still not done with the main quest, but I give this game an 8.5 out of 10 and here's why:

tldr at the bottom...

Graphically, the game is absolutely breathtaking.  The environments, character models, cutscenes, and rendering is superb.  Sometimes while playing the game, I just have to pause and look around at the mountains, forests, and seas and marvel.  

Gameplay and combat feels a lot smoother than The Witcher 2.  Playing with a mouse and keyboard is truly where the controls shine.  I originally started playing with a controller, but I had to ditch it after a couple of minutes.  The game needs to be played with the mouse and keyboard.  

Controls can be really overwhelming though.  I originally began playing this game during college when it first released, but classes and work hindered me from really enjoying the game, so I had to put it down for weeks at a time.  Giving me plenty of time to forget what the control scheme was.  Now that I have my own life and work, I used my 2-week vacation break to really dig into the game and give it a go.  That's how it deserves to be played.  Unlike Skyrim where I can play it for 30 minutes, set it down and play it later, this game usually requires my attention for a couple of hours a day if not more.  

The story and side quests are amazing thus far.  Well written and tugs on your heart-strings in some instances.  Like I mentioned, at this time I haven't completed the main quest, but it's still really enjoyable.  The amount of choices you can make is wonderful, and sometimes you have to make split-second decisions in dialog.  

Lastly is soundtrack and sound design.  I could listen to the music in this game for days on end.  The last time I felt that strongly about a game's soundtrack was Darksiders: II.  I really enjoy the music and it doesn't bother me like Skyrim's did at one time (it was just a phase.  I grew out of it.).  As for the sound design, excellent.  You really feel like a Witcher with the various sounds you hear coming from the woods or off the trails.  Wander around outside of cities in the Wilderness and you'll get what I mean.  

The only cons I have are the glitches and bugs.  Sometimes cutscenes will begin and characters will perpetually be casting a noisy spell or have a weapon drawn or holding a random object but not really holding it (just sort of glued to the palm of their hand).  That can really take you out of the immersion.  Occasionally, a group of other npcs or animals will flock through your cutscene, blocking your view of characters and what's going on.  This happened to me while doing a rescue mission.  Whole herd of deer wandered into our little camp and just stood inside the characters while we talked around a campfire.  Sometimes characters clothes won't load, so there will be some floating heads and hands.  As long as this game has been out, you'd think they'd fix something like that (unless it was patched in the GotY edition).  

So that's my review.  As stated before 8.5/10.  Deducting 0.5 points for the vast amount of keybinds and control schemes you have to remember.  1.0 point for the glitches and bugs throughout the game.  Some of them are immersive breaking, but not game breaking.  

tldr: game's really good. 8.5/10. has some bugs and glitches that break immersion.  need to dedicate a lot of time to play it, or else you might forget controls.  that's it. see ya.

Listen. I just played the whole trilogy from start to finish. I cannot recommend this game or any in the series to anyone. When a game has issues you fix them, you don't replace them with all new issues. CDPR spent too much time trying to find the mechanics they wanted to ever try improving on what they had and the result is that 1 has the best character customization in terms of number of choices, while 2 has the most meaningless choices, 3 tried to go back to 1's style but in a different way and ultimately came off as too simplified. The best controls go to 2, which was okay but still had some issues. All of them are walking simulator RPG's and should gain the tag Walking Simulator due to the lack of useful fast travel points built into the games themselves if any at all. If you don't enjoy walking/running or riding a horse that is barely faster than Geralt for five to ten minutes at a time don't buy this game or any in the series. What makes this game a hot mess is that the story even going from game to game required me to look to outside sources to connect the events. This is a big no-no that game developers need to stop doing. It didn't work well for Blizzard and it equally bad here. I shouldn't feel forced to purchase books or movies to follow a plot. That's just corporate greed attempting to milk it's customer base. This series in short made me angry and annoyed that a developer could make such terrible choices and get so much defense for it with people citing "characters" or "story" or "gameplay" all of which are subpar at best and irritating at worst. The real kick to the groin was when the games focused on people other than Geralt which was unfortunately unavoidable as the nature of the Witcher is that he is a sort of narrator or chronicler of events that the player sees the world through. Dandelion is annoying, Triss is annoying, Zoltan was a bore almost seemingly written to appease the "bro" crowd with his fratboy behavior, Shani being tossed into DLC was BS meant to milk fans, I'm not buying DLC even if the girl I chose in the first game is in it, not cool CDPR. Ciri was written like a common rebellious teen outside of her main story events and it was jarringly bad for someone with the wherewithal to plot a divide and conquer strategy to turn around and want to do bad things because the person we are doing them to is bad. It also flew in the face of many choices in the game that lead to an ending you can only get when you show her the value of being a decent human being, which according to the developers is a manic psychopath as one reaction is to vent like a ***** and throw crap around. Please note that I will never travel to Poland as apparently the way my oldest sister behaves is okay and I prefer to NOT have my car stolen to go kidnap children from child services. Finally let's talk about the overly simple plot every likes to tote around. It was common fantasy garbage and taking your sweet time in getting around to it doesn't make it any better. We have a chosen one which isn't you, done before, who has to save the world, done before, from an otherwise unstoppable force that no one can comprehend, done before. The journey was just as bad as the destination. Either the original works CDPR used aren't all that great or CDPR just stinks at making games. Either way I'm on to Cyberpunk this summer but I'm taking a break from that one and at least giving them a chance to fix their broken garbage.

I was saving this critique for last because I wanted this to end on a positive note. There are good things about this game. It's beautiful even now 6 years after release I find it has graphical quality that almost rivals modern AAA titles. Using graphics mods only makes it better and far tops even the most expensive AAA titles out there now. Well done graphics team. I also would like to take a moment to acknowledge how generally bug free a game of this size is. Compared to Skyrim or other massive world titles I expected so many bugs, I expected to fall through the ground at some point.

I would like to see CDPR make a homebrew IP instead of using other IP's at some point. It's clear they don't understand mechanics for the life of them but they can make some stunning visuals and managed to follow a janky slav story long enough to hammer out three games from it's novels. Especially if the titles are small enough to let them make an in house IP of it without stretching the budget.
A true masterpiece. You NEED to play this game before death call you.

The hardest thing about this game is trying to split your time between simping for Ciri and doing Witcher shit.  Both offer great...satisfaction, but the side quests and Witcher contracts is what really gets my rocks off.  I put around 100 or so hours on my PS4 and I thoroughly enjoyed that version, despite it's glaring flaws on the base console.  Playing on PC was a breath of fresh air.  I stretched my playthough to nearly 130 hours and I am fixing to do a new game +.

Simultaneously the best single-player RPG story I've experienced to date and most infuriating movement controls and mechanics.  A wonderful "Winds howling."/10.

- "Run Roach!" *Gets stuck on literally nothing while passing through an archway or over a small bridge.*
- *Swims in awkward circles trying to get the loot option to pop up at the bottom of a lake or bay.*
- *Gets stuck on something while trying to swim out of a cave, sunken ship, or underwater ruin with 30% breath left.*
- *Ignites candles, chandeliers, & lanterns while trying to loot a crate or chest.*
- *While fighting multiple enemies at once.* "Damnit Geralt, quit targeting that one!"
- *While attempting to run from an enemy because you're so fed up fighting it while passing through that area.* "QUIT TURNING AROUND!"
- *Whistles to call Roach.* *Meanwhile in a non-parallel universe Roach spawns a mile away and gets stuck on every fence, tree, bush, and BLADE OF GRASS on his way over.*
- *Fight starts and Geralt decides to use his fists.*  "Geralt, draw your sword.  Geralt, draw your sword please?  Geralt, draw your @!#$!%& sword!"
- *Geralt trips while going down stairs.*
- *Geralt decides it's time to ski back down an incline.*
- *After a cutscene Geralt's decoctions disappear, is thrown into a fight, and those same decoctions haven't been replenished.*

In all seriousness, this game was quite the adventure.  I got the worst ending not just once, but twice because at the time there were no in-depth guides on how to get the best ending.  I also failed several side quests I wasn't aware needed to be completed before progressing the main story or that were dependent upon certain outcomes.  In each of those playthroughs I had at least 100%'d White Orchard and Skellige or Velen/Novigrad as well.  It hurt - was demoralizing even.  After a few years of putting it off I'd finally built up the willpower to complete the perfect playthrough - the best Witcher 2 simulation, the best endings to all quests and story lines, all quests completed (none failed), and 100%'d every area (White Orchard, Velen/Novigrad, Skellige, & Toussaint).  I've done it.  It is finished and I can finally head into New Game+ knowing that I at least did everything right or to my liking at least once.

A few things I would have changed about this perfect playthrough:
- Set the difficulty to Death March before starting and kept it there for the achievement. (My perfect playthrough being my 3rd or 4th time, I didn't want to deal with the struggle.  In hindsight, I think I could have handled it.)
- Disabled enemy upscaling. (This is because there were level 1 rats during a quest which would instakill Geralt due to a problem in the enemy upscaling option.  You can also tell when some enemies fail to get upscaled, some don't, and others receive a buff.  Disabling this option would have also made Death March easier.)

Folks have plenty of gripes with the game and it does need a few quality of life changes but we'll probably never see another update as they're working on a new Witcher game that doesn't feature Geralt as the main protagonist.  I personally was annoyed by some of the bugs I encountered in Toussaint.  It shows that they either pushed the expansion out before it was ready or the development skills of members who might've helped with Cyberbug 2077 started showing:
- White horses spawning in the middle of the street stuck inside each other or blocking doorways into shops.
- NPCs' limbs and clothes going invisible.
- After leaving the merchant near the Nilfgardian embassy the world disintegrated.  Walls, doors, many things went invisible and couldn't be interacted with.  I could see under the map and had to load an old save just to resolve the issue.

Regardless, this is definitely a game - no, a world and a life - worth experiencing.

Tips for new players:
- Take your time.  Take in the sights, smell the flowers, savor the conversations, relationships, and story.  No reason to feel rushed or push until after your first playthrough.
- Save your game often and as a new save!  Quicksave is F5 on the keyboard otherwise you'll need to enter the menu and manually save if using a controller.  You'll never know when something bad will happen (death, outcomes, etc.) and will need/want to reload to try again.
- Play Gwent at every opportunity.  Win cards from opponents and diffuse bad situations while you still can.
- Take all posts from notice boards.  They consist of contracts, side quests, and points of interest.
- Do side quests, contracts, treasure hunts, and explore points of interest before progressing the story.
- Purchase maps from vendors if available - especially in Skellige - to reveal fast travel signs.
- Read your Bestiary for tips on what oils, signs, and potions to use against monsters.
- Loot monsters.
- Loot destroyed monster nests.
- Loot everything out of a guards sight.
- Sell common, magic, and master-crafted weapons and armor you don't need.  Keep relics.
- Dismantle junk for materials or sell it.
- Craft oils, potions, and decoctions as you can.
- Only craft Witcher gear (Cat, Griffin, Wolf, Viper, Manticore, &/or Bear).  There are very few relics that end up actually being better than these sets.  I personally went with Cat (light, bleeds, faster attacks) and upgraded it to Grandmaster.  You can get all the diagrams for every set however it's more efficient to choose and stick with one.
- After killing a monster that grants a trophy, ensure Roach still has the trophy you want equipped.
one of the best games ever made, with an incredible story and sub stories i guarantee you'll never run out of things to do in this game.

Probably the best game ever made. I have just started playing and I still have a lot to learn in this beautiful and realistic world. The main characters are well made and very charming, the game is perfect in almost every way. Anyone who hasn't played this game loses some of the creative genius.
Amazing game. Can't really say more than that.

Not a fan of RPGs mostly. I actually put this game on the ignore list for a long time so I didn't have steam recommend it every time I visited the store page. I bought cyberpunk thinking I'll try that because I like FPSs and Fallout 3 was a lot of fun to me back in the day. I uninstalled it after the first few hours because of bugs and just generally wanting the game to be better. Then I revisited this store page. It was the winter sale. 15 bucks for an entire game and DLCs with people saying just get it? Okay

I am now 40 hours in after 5 days and I actually don't know where the time is going. This is one of the greatest games I have ever played and I am barely half way through it. I never knew an RPG can make you feel like you're actually in a story. It's incredible. And the intuitive fight mechanics make you want to get better and better at fighting. I feel like a god when I can pull off combos against multiple enemies without being touched. 

10/10

Played the game around 300 hours. Despite its beautiful story and artistic world design there are some serious problems. 
It's combat is boring, All you have to do is spamming left click of your mouse and you'll simply win, Doesn't matter either you're facing Eredin or killing a tiny Nekker. It always  works. It means you can finish the game without using any bombs and potions or that clunky crossbow. but some enemies like spiders in Hearts of Stone are somehow more challenging.
The game's side activities like horse races or feast fights are soooooo simple to win. I NEED more challenging hobbies in a game which is called a MASTERPIECE. 
The lackage of Upgrading weapons can be felt. When you gain a non-witcher set there's no way to upgrade it to your lvl and it will be useless then.

The most complete, well-written, polished videogame I have ever played. So much content to play through, and not only is it as long as you want it to be, all that time that you will spend in this world will be a joy, because every single mechanic is extremely well done and implemented. It is because of games like these that I will never stop playing videogames in the future. I only wish I could play Witcher III for the first time again, to experience it without knowing the amazingness that awaited me.

Did not enjoy this game. Main questline is too boring as it feels repetitive (In order to find someone, you have to find another, then find something for that someone and repeat). I did not enjoy the health mechanism and I would have liked a more customisable armor set where you can manually do stuff to alter the armor stats based on your level. Lastly the levelling up system is so stupid, if I level up I would like something like runescape where you can focus on different skills and there is a huge variety there. In this game there isnt much skills to work on and even if you do unlock skills you can only use a certain number. 3/10. No Recommendo

I think after 30 something hours of playing the game I am ready to write down a review. I will try to keep it as concise as possible. 
Story: 
You follow the path of the Witcher and his many adventures. Yes, there is the main quest, but there is also tons of side quests, I am almost finished with the second book "Sword of Destiny" and I feel that the game is capturing the soul and the feel of the books very well. It does feel like playing the Witcher with all the monster contracts, the wretches you meet along the way and the odd turns that you face. It never ceases to be interesting, the world is huge and from what I have seen so far, the story is faithful to the overall lore of the Witcher universe. 
Even if you didn't read the books the story will absorb you nevertheless. 

Graphics:
6 years later and it still looks very beautiful, thankfully, this game depends not only on technical beauty but also artistic beauty which is timeless. It runs very smooth on my GTX 1080Ti @4k with almost everything maxed except for hairworks. 

Sound:
The voice acting is superbly done, probably the best I have ever seen in any game. [spoiler]I was mesmerized specially at the part where the old woman is possessed by the three sisters and they speak through her. [/spoiler]. 
Musical score is also some of the best I heard, it switches between ambient exploration music and in fights it becomes intense folklore music, the vocal parts are amazingly done as well. It also changes to fit the story and the mood. 

Gameplay:
No game is perfect, and I feel that The Witcher 3 falls a bit short on gameplay. The fights, while fun, they are simple, or rather simpler than Witcher 2 and Witcher 1. That is not my issue though, my real issue is with alchemy, it had been dumbed down so much to the point that it became generic. To create a potion, all you have to do is collect the ingredients only once and then your potions and bombs will regenerate every time you meditate through consuming Alcohest which is very simple. 
This greatly kills the immersion for me. Part of the fun in Witcher 1 and 2 was when I meditate before a major hunt and I prepare and drink my potions during the meditation phase. It felt real and it felt like what would a Witcher do before a fight. I know this was an attempt from CDPR to make the game more mainstream but I can live with that. 
As for Gwent, I haven't enjoyed a minigame like this since triple triad on Final Fantasy 8 and 9. It is extremely well done and very very fun and interesting to play. I won't spoil it for you but if you enjoyed triple triad, you will love Gwent. 

Closing words:
It is hard to believe that this game came from the same company that created CB2077, the attention to detail is insane and all the quests feel like they have been handcrafted without exceptions. 
For maximum enjoyment, I highly recommend that you at least play the first two witcher games, you can get them both for pennies.

Absolutely mint game, in my top 3 easy

An ambitious, atmospheric, story-rich and deeply involving RPG that actually delivers.

The main story itself is incredibly engaging, but it's hard to not get sucked into all the complex sidequests along the way. There were a few moments where I felt like the game was leaning into tired fantasy tropes that I wasn't really a fan of, but I was ultimately either proven wrong, or there were other aspects or story beats that more than balanced out those for me.

On top of that, I also found Witcher 3 to be reasonably accessible to new players, or even ones who were just here to play the easy Adventure Mode. The world's deep lore and complex backstory could seem daunting, but instead I found myself intrigued to learn more with every dialogue Geralt was having, and find out more about our character along the way.

I did experience some lags in my cutscenes and even gameplay (chiefly during storms), but that was most likely the result of some of my PC properties being below the adviced requirements, and even with that, the game remained extremely enjoyable. I also managed to get myself stuck 2 or 3 times, and experienced a bug in the final act where a cutscene wasn't triggered, but I wasn't bothered much thanks to the satisfactory autosave functions.

Overall, this game has something for everyone, even a fun minigame in Gwynt, that I can't stop playing now.

It's the Witcher 3, I think we all know how good this game is. It's not the best game for people who don't like sitting through a lot of storytelling, nor is it a game for someone who want to get through a game quickly. It'll take at least 25-30hr of your time, even if you run through the story campaign and the romance questlines only. But for most gamers, W3 is one you cannot miss.
BEST RPG IVE EVER PLAYED HANDS DOWN 10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMED
jogo muito bom, so nao gosto de andar de cavalo e jogar o jogo de carta, fora isso e perfeito

Cuando pense que ya no me podia sorprender ningun juego de rol me dejo callado y bien pillo. 
Excelente hilo argumental, jugabilidad, ambientacion, graficos; a dia de hoy no le encontre ningun aspecto negativo, la verdad una joya.
Everything is great but the mechanic of movement is pretty weird to me and there are bugs in game.

So much to do, so much to see in one of the most visually stunning games (even in 2021) you'll potentially encounter. The story itself is diverse and rich, and there's enough content to keep you wanting more without getting stale.

If you're a bit let down by the launch of Cyberpunk and looking for the sheer brilliance of a CDPR title once the bugs are ironed out (The Witcher had as many bugs as CP has on launch). Give this a go!

Probably the most amount of time time I've spent in a single player RPG. Combined with the GoG version, I have over 300 (specifically 215 hours on Steam, and 100 on GoG) hours spent in the game. I would 100% recommend this game to any person; the amount of detail put in this game shows how much time and passion the developers put into it. This can be seen from the world's detailed characters, the story, the subtle differences in the story dependent on the choices you make, and the detailed side quests. 5 years later, closing in on 6, I believe other developers working on open-world RPGs should strive to add the kind of detail like the Wild Hunt had (because honestly, I'm fed up with open-world games).

The only major complaint I had is with some morally ambiguous side quests, which significantly limit the player's choice, especially when considering a Witcher's arsenal. That being said, once again I'd like to emphasize, I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this game to anyone interested in a single player RPG.

The Witcher 3 does not respect my time. 7.8/10 dont recommend if you have literately anything else that requires major commitment...like a job and family if you want to get through this game in less than a couple months

As an Rpg in some aspects it is impressive but lacking in any meaningfulness decent with some purpose or lacking in understanding of how to address problems that have plagued RPGS (and would need to tackle to deserve the praise it does IMO) This game may have lots of content but that doesn't matter when you feel like you are going nowhere in terms of progression and overall feels like more spectacle than substance.

Let me start off my criticism with the most....i want to say....immediately pressing and would be instantly brushed off as a illegitimate criticism: the open world. Open worlds have come a long way but they have had problems that have been addressed and similar to criticisms of certain games that have hub worlds, yes you might have side quests and little caves that might have a enemy or 5 and a chest or 2, but side-quests are guided by level and have a level system in an open world game isn't inherently bad but when you give me shit from the DLC and like level 37 quests i can find at level 7 (IF I EXPLORE WHICH IS LIKE THE ENTIRE PURPOSE OF AN OPEN WORLD) it would have been better to split up places and have a more streamlined experience and not risk me finding end game stuff at levels where that shit dont and wont matter until i have invested 100+ hours (and has been solved in other rpgs (and solved in a really popular one that has re-released more times than my niece has lived in years *hint**hint) btw)) in and with how shallow the main way of progression is *cough**cough* bad combat system *cough**cough* (aside from the stories told cause in terms of that the main quests  stories they tell are decent and only really never drop lower than mundane with slight intrigue which is something that 99 percent of other games especially in this genre NEVER come close to which is saddening as rpgs are up there for me along with action and platforming in terms of how much I like them)) with the depth-less fluff that is most of the side-side-content like the caves and little areas and things to that extent that are as shallow of content i have seen in many RPGS but praised here as "not necessary stuff they just happened to put in for US, yes worship company" and here is one of the major problems further facilitated by "side content" in rpgs *ahem* SIDE CONTENT IS NOT SIDE CONTENT IF YOU NEED TO DO IT TO PROGRESS TO A POINT THAT YOU CAN DO MORE "INTERESTING" *cough**cough* bad combat system *cough**cough* (in this one) SHIT, WHICH 1. RPGS FROM THE 1990s TO NOW HAVE SUFFERED FROM and 2. A GAME WOULD NEED TO ADDRESS TO BE CONSIDERED THE BEST GAME/RPG OF ALL TIME BECAUSE BELIEVE IT OR NOT IT WOULDN'T BE A PROBLEM IF HOW YOU PROGRESS WASN'T SO SCATTER-BRAINED and  is resolved with better consideration of the risk and problems of having an open world & a leveling system that has been done better in games where there 1. weren't any open worlds and 2 had the devs consider progression and added solutions like the level of a quest being determined by your current level, or enough experience to when you experience that section you'd be the right level to progress, etc. To me it seems the open world was put in not to be genuine used fully consistently or of better quality as a game than games without one like in nondescript nintendo paper styled rpg from early 2000s (the last good one on nondescript cube console) & other nondescript open-world fanatsy nintendo rpg from late/mid 2010s on nondescript handled and portable console but more as spectacle that ended up hurting how you progress through it which AGAIN has been solved for YEARS and further contributes to me not seeing eye to eye on people that over-indulge in the fantasy that is this game being better than like a 7.8/10 from a company that was praised until recently, that has put up a good face of pro-consumerism in the eyes of the gaming landscape (& seems to me why some think its better than it is)

DO YOU WANT TO TALK ABOUT THE FUCKED COMBAT SYSTEM THAT IS SO MEDIOCRE AND FLAWED THAT IT FORCES ME TO THINK THAT PEOPLE THINK THIS GAME IS 10/10 ARE 100% BUTT-FUCK FUCKING INSANE. First of let me list the problems then go more in depth with them: lack of complexity, stuttery fucking mess (partly to blame is the movement system), problems with communication and lack of impact due to it.

Complexity: At most the complexity of this combat system is select one ability that is the obvious weakness of the enemy use it and kill it or allow it to be damaged then wait to do again. Nothing really offensive here but expecting this to support a game for more than 8 hours is a fucken pipe dream and the enchanting system only insults this system really and screams the most surface level and actually a slight lack of understanding on how to make a combat system fun.

stuttery fucking limiting mess: This game has lock on and movement  system worse than darksouls and darksouls doesnt have to most complex or better than average movement system in terms of mechanical skill needed (Dark Souls however uses the parameters that it does have masterfully though) and due to this lack complexity you'd think it be good just fundamentally and this is were i must express this idea: 1.movement is the most important thing to nail even in an RPG (it doesnt have to be complex btw it just has to be good enough for the feel you want & used in a way where you understand its limits & use what you do have masterfully (ie. DarkSouls...again)) and 2. Animation based movement (rather than just pure parameter/programmed with animation made to match up or not depending on how lazy you are feeling when programming/animating-based movement that doesn't take into account some mundane parts if the world like a small ditch in a dirt road for example (unless you let physics take over small details but even then if the ditch is deep enough it wont look realistic) Isnt always the answer and actually is less responsive if implemented poorly like it is here. It is done really well in things like Shadow of War (where lots of predictions are used and could have aspects of real-time animation used but still seems to be animation based (CORRECT ME IF I AM WRONG HERE)) and an example of good control without pure animation based movement A Hat In Time (the best platformers have gotten in terms of base mechanics though it could still be improved and slight side tangent: (UNDERSTAND THE IMPORTANCE OF USING THE CAMERA'S FORWARD VECTOR instead of the CHARACTER'S in certain circumstances AND IT'll MAKE YOUR GAME BETTER... if you know how to use it right when making a platformer or any game for that matter it'd be better... fuck realism and/or oversights in impact of a small detail as such and improve game feel) Anyway back on topic, Wicther 3's movement when walking around relatively flat or spacious and kinda round terrain seems fine then add trees and attack tracking & the same 1 or 2 animations when attacking and the problem is exacerbated if not semi-consistent in its effect; getting stuck on terrain and being zoomed up if in jutting and spike like terrain happens and thus the realism achieved in the walking cycle MEANS EVEN LESS THAN THE NOTHING IT SHOULD.

"problems with communication and lack of impact due to it": now you might think"communication what the fuck is this talking about?" but show the general point animation and effects are used to what? To show you and communicate to you what the fuck is happening. Witcher has this problem when doing heavy attacks/bad use particle effects when attacking in general & thus the problem of lack impact occurs due to it. and to i realized that i reached the word count when trying to add more at some point but i have many more problems here than stated here i could go into quests and the good of it. :D

Dans mon top 3 des meilleurs jeux auxquels j'ai jouÃ© de ma vie
- Une carte immense
- Un Bestiaire super riche
- Le genre de level design qui te fait souvent t'arrÃ©tÃ© pour admirer le travail d'orfÃ¨vre rÃ©alisÃ©
- L'histoire est tellement bien racontÃ©e

Pros:
 - A rich and complete RPG experience with a wide variety of high quality quests.
- An ambitious scope that was very expertly executed, and nearly incomparable to anything else made so far. 
- The quest quality is pretty consistent throughout the game, even over a hundred hours in, you'd think the game wouldn't be able to keep up with the level of detail that it offers in the first hours, yet it does exactly that and then some.
- Great story and writing, from the main quest to the smaller quests and the stories and characters that you'll encounter, lots of detail and love were poured all over this world, some of which you might not even encounter on your first playthrough. Any and all sorts of emotions and moments that you'll probably remember for years to come.
- Decisions you make have a pretty substantial impact in the story and on other characters, making you feel the weight of responsibility, some of the choices are surprisingly difficult to make.
- Substantially different endings based on your choices.
- The game doesn't pull many punches when it comes to the number romantic options that it offers, some will even influence certain aspects of the story, it's romantic when it needs to be, it's sexy when it needs to be, and at times pretty funny.
- Gameplay has taken what was made in the earlier installments, build upon it and create a very polished and intuitive improvement, the combat feels amazing and personal, with you being able to find your own play style and groove. It plays like a smooth action-adventure game despite being a massive and comprehensive RPG.
- A character upgrade system that will allow you to improve Geralt's fighting, signs (which are basically spells) and alchemy which influences your effectiveness with potions and bombs. Offering more in the way of play-style customization.
- Tons of different weapons and gear that you can use, as-well to different effects that you can add.
- The visuals are great, with an amazing art direction, I have no doubt that this game will age pretty well.
- The world is beautiful to look at, from the different cities, to small villages, islands, mountains and forests, this game has some of the most realistic forests and green environments that I've seen in game, there's a really nice chaotic feel of how trees and plants are placed which makes it feel very natural. The weather system directly impacts how everything looks and the world and even NPCs react to it accordingly. One of the best day/night cycles that I've seen in a open world, dusk and sun rise can at times look absolutely stunning.
- Beautiful music throughout the game.
- Great DLCs that add tens of hours of content, none of it feels lazy or by the numbers, instead it feels like genuine contributions to the world, with some of the writing and quests being of higher quality than even most of what we've encountered in the main game, which was already pretty good. Blood and Wine in particular is probably the single best story-based DLC that I've seen in a game. 
- Gwent is an awesome addition to the franchise, and far superior to the prior mini-games.

Cons:

- I've experience multiple crashes, and by multiple, I really mean it. This game crashed a lot. And I know for a fact that this is a game issue and not a system issue, because this level of frequent crashing only happened when played The Witcher 3, in fact, I have yet to experience this problem on their newest Cyberpunk game or on any other game that I'm currently playing. Very unfortunate and by my far my biggest issue with this game and what prevents it from being a 10/10 in my eyes.

- The in-game economy is very unbalanced, I find myself very often finding most of the weapons and gear that I need just by exploring the world, I consistently found swords that were an immediate upgrade to swords that I've just picked not long ago, giving me very little incentive to explore crafting or buy weapons from stores, if anything, I mostly used stores to get gold from selling the excess weapons and gear that I would frequently find in the game world. The exception being when I wanted a particular armor that I would only get through crafting.

- The menus and in-game interface although you'll eventually get used to it, its not the most intuitive.

- The game could have offered more way for me to spend my gold, like buying houses, decoration and properties. The Blood and Wine DLC introduces some of that in the game, thought because you're supposed to play it after the main campaign, it all comes a bit too late. Would be awesome to have had a place to improve and decorate with different items from my different adventures, earlier in the game, maybe even have some of the main characters drop by. Though I do realize this is less of a flaw and more of a personal wish and nitpick.

Overall:

The Witcher 3 is arguably one of the best RPGs ever made, if not the best, if you're a fan of the genre or if you are curious about what a CDPR game looks at its best, I definitely recommend you to skip on Cyberpunk 2077 until they fix it, and instead dive into the world of the Witcher and learn exactly why this studio became so beloved by so many gamers. This is an awesome journey that has pretty much everything a game could offer, an immersive world and story that will keep you interested, lots to do and explore and you'll always feel in control of the pace of which you want to experience the game. If you want to pick up the game to just do some quick Witcher contracts and slash some monsters, you can, if you want to just walk, swim, ride and sail around the massive world and probably always finding something in the process, you can. If you want to just play Gwent and collect new cards from NPCs you can, and if you want to experience one of the best video-game stories and story-based quests ever written and designed, The Witcher 3 will be there for you with very little risk of leaving you disappointed.

From the main storyline to the smallest quest u can really tell that they were made with direct concept. The moral dilemas and choices are in point. The characters are fenomenal. Only some parts of gameplay like clunking moving or some level buildings are  sometimes annoying, but besides this it's a great game.

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt ist der 3. Teil in der groÃŸartigen Witcher Serie. Erneut Ã¼bernimmt man die Rolle des Hexers Geralt, der sich durch eine wunderschÃ¶ne Welt voll Monster und interessanter Charaktere kÃ¤mpft um seine Ziehtochter Ciri zu finden und die gefÃ¤hrliche Wilde Jagd aufzuhalten. Dabei benutzt er magische Zeichen, Schwerter und sein unglaubliches Charisma um sich den Gefahren dieser Welt zu stellen. Auch alte Bekannte wie Triss, Rittersporn und Yennefer sind wieder mit von der Partie.

Positives:
- eine riesige Open World mit Tonnen an Orten und Geheimnissen zu erkunden
- wunderschÃ¶ne, abwechslungsreiche Szenerie mit groÃŸartiger Grafik
- anspruchsvolle Boss-KÃ¤mpfe
- Tonnen von Nebenmissionen
- groÃŸartige Story
- unglaublich viele interessante Charaktere zum kennenlernen
- deine Entscheidungen beeinflussen die Story
- sehr viele verschiedene Enden
- groÃŸartige DLCs die die Story und Map nochmal um zig Spielstunden erweitern

Negatives:
- der Fallschaden ist Ã¼bertrieben hoch. Wenn Geralt vom Sessel runterfÃ¤llt stirbt er. (Ja gut das ist jetzt Ã¼bertrieben, aber es bringt es ca auf den Punkt)
- Im Wikingergebiet gibt es zu viele Banditenverstecke (Ihr werdet noch sehen wovon ich spreche)

Zusammenfassung:
The Witcher 3 ist in meinen Augen das beste Spiel, das bisher je produziert wurde. Es macht unglaublich viel SpaÃŸ und bietet auch die MÃ¶glichkeit einen erneuten Durchlauf zu starten ohne die Story zweimal gleich gespielt zu haben. Man kann stundenlang nur durch die Welt reiten und sich wunderschÃ¶ne SonnenuntergÃ¤nge anschauen. Es ist abwechslungsreich und hÃ¤lt einen durchgehend bei Laune. Das perfekte Spiel fÃ¼r Fantasy Fans die nach eine sehr umfangreichen Spiel suchen. (Ja 159 Stunden war ein Durchlauf plus Dlcs)

Celui-ci a Ã©tÃ© retravaillÃ©, mais il reste des aspects qui me laissent perplexe. Avant de les aborder, les points positifs qui se distinguent des autres jeux RPG et qui donnent une identitÃ© au jeu :

- Les lieux visitÃ©s, on sent que ce n'est pas du copy-paste habituel dans certains jeux en monde ouvert, certes les PNJ en ville ont des clones mais l'ambiance dans les villes est crÃ©dible, et pour s'immerger dans un jeu, c'est plaisant.

- Le gameplay, mÃªme s'il y a des failles, tranche un peu des autres jeux, chaque monstre ayant ses faiblesses, on peut bien sÃ»r y aller Ã  la mode bourrin et ne rien lire du monstre que l'on combat mais le combat se prolonge de fait deux fois plus longtemps.

- Les moments "creux" de l'histoire, incarner Ciri, les cinÃ©matiques Ã  foison pour tout dÃ©roulement, d'accord, c'est sympa mais Ã  la longue 3 cinÃ©matiques pour une courte phase de gameplay, on sent bien que les dÃ©veloppeurs aiment montrer ce qu'ils ont fait plutÃ´t que de laisser le joueur agir Ã  sa guise.

- Les combats en endgame, ce qui m'a fait quitter le jeu et ne pas tenter le mode new game +, armure complÃ¨te faite, amÃ©liorations au max et...plus rien en face qui rÃ©siste. Ce qui faisait le sel du combat au dÃ©but du jeu tourne Ã  la farce, plus besoin d'esquiver, on spamme une attaque tournoyante sur des ennemis chargeant sur vous, regen et buff sur chaque victime et c'est pliÃ©.

- Le principe du newgame +, peu de jeux ont ce systÃ¨me, d'ordinaire c'est "tu finis le jeu, youhou, prends ta tablette de chocolat et regarde les crÃ©dits dÃ©filer, plus qu'Ã  tout recommencer". En soi je suppose que tout est rÃ©initialisÃ©, mais au fond quel intÃ©rÃªt hormis choisir l'inverse de ce que l'on a choisi pendant l'histoire ? Niveau gameplay, ce seront les mÃªme ennemis plus forts qui ralentiront la progression Ã  mesure jusqu'Ã  reprendre le cycle "je tue tout ce qui bouge" dÃ©crit juste avant.

- Les bugs, alors lÃ  difficile de ne pas en avoir au moins un pendant toute une partie et quand on voit ce qui s'est passÃ© avec Cyberpunk, les prÃ©mices Ã©taient dÃ©jÃ  lÃ ...

- La gestion de l'inventaire du personnage, catastrophique, on a bien un coffre mais faire le tri dans les objets que l'on ramasse entre le nÃ©cessaire (armes, armure, outils pour rÃ©parer armes et armures) et l'accessoire (chaque objet peut Ãªtre pris sans que l'on sache concrÃ¨tement s'il peut Ãªtre recyclÃ©, vendu directement ou complÃ¨tement inutile) est une corvÃ©e. On ne sait plus quoi choisir Ã  rÃ©cupÃ©rer, et j'en suis venu Ã  me dire, je me limite aux armes/armures, ce qui rend l'intÃ©rÃªt des autres objets Ã  foison Ã  rÃ©cupÃ©rer trÃ¨s limitÃ© voire inutile.

- Le monde "ouvert", gros point mis en avant qui...n'en est pas un au sens propre, on a plusieurs cartes, plus ou moins grandes, oui, mais pour aller de l'une Ã  l'autre, Ã©cran de chargement avec le rÃ©sumÃ© de l'histoire prÃ©sente. La premiÃ¨re fois, Ã§a paraÃ®t sympathique, la 10e fois, Ã§a devient longuet. Si le studio s'est aperÃ§u que beaucoup de joueurs ne terminaient pas l'histoire, c'est justement qu'il y a plethorre de quÃªtes secondaires, assez soignÃ©es mais remettre le fil rouge en avant Ã  chaque fois "coucou, tu t'Ã©tais arrÃªtÃ© lÃ  au fait", non, je ne suis pas un poisson rouge, merci.

- Le leveling, impossible de grapiller la moindre expÃ©rience en tuant des ennemis (hormis les nids de monstres), tout passe par des quÃªtes, elle-mÃªme Ã  des niveaux prÃ©cis. Le jeu Ã©vite l'Ã©cueil de farm de niveau, certes, mais c'est aussi une faÃ§on dÃ©tournÃ©e de dire "j'ai envie que tu fasses ce que j'ai programmÃ©, et si Ã§a ne te plaÃ®t pas, tu resteras Ã  taper avec ton Ã©pÃ©e en mousse".

What more can I add to previous reviews? Not much. This game is the best game I have ever played. 
Even after all these years the game looks astonishing (and the modding community did an amazing job bringing this game to its full graphical potential). 
The story is interesting and addictive, the side quests are meaningful, the characters are likable and you do care about them. I really liked how side quests intertwined with the main story is masterfully done.
And the best of all â€“ it stays true to the bookâ€™s lore and atmosphere, which is engrossing. CD project red did an amazing job, and I can not state enough how much I appreciate what the did in this regard.
If by any change you still did not play this game, please do. The best experience gaming has to offer.

Good game, I played too many hours over a short period of time though and tired myself out - I wouldn't recommend travelling and discovering most locations as they are mainly the same with similar enemies. Combat is fun and challenging on the hardest difficulty, I would recommend doing this in addition to turning on level scaling and also increasing the Gwent difficulty. If you dislike combat you can always reduce the difficulty.
